title: Finance, Legal & Education Domains
content:
Section 5.1.2 · Multi-Agent

Domain Applications

Finance

The financial domain can be decomposed into four archetypal roles: analysts, risk managers, traders/execution agents, and compliance officers. This division reflects the established institutional design of financial organizations.

  • Analysts operate at different levels (fundamental, sentiment, or technical), each extracting distinct signals from raw market or textual data
  • Risk Managers monitor portfolio exposure, apply stress tests, and enforce safeguards to prevent cascading vulnerabilities
  • Traders take responsibility for market interaction, ensuring orders are placed with speed and efficiency
  • Compliance roles ensure activities remain aligned with regulatory requirements

Legal Activities

Multi-agent systems are designed to model the collaborative and adversarial processes inherent in legal practice, with roles assigned to manage consultation, reasoning, and argumentation:

  • For legal consultation, frameworks feature a receptionist agent for client intake, specialized lawyer agents for providing advice, and a boss agent for quality control
  • For statutory reasoning, tasks are decomposed between knowledge acquisition agents and knowledge application agents

Analysis & Explanation

Domain Adaptation

Key Pattern

Each domain naturally suggests role structures that mirror human expertise divisions. The most successful multi-agent systems leverage existing organizational knowledge rather than inventing new structures.
